ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In addition to seminars, we had a couple of guest speakers and one-on-one meetings with the professor.
We also had live speakers come in on some days.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to successfully write literary analyses and incorporate research.

We read a variety of world literatures in this course -- the course is not a survey, rather more of an exploration of works written by authors from different post-colonial countries and some of the difficulties posed by having a so-called "world literatures" class. We developed insight on how to possibly respond to those difficulties and questions through discussion in class, working with some archival material, meeting scholars in the field (even an author of one of the works we read), and forming our own conclusions through three papers as well as a "Worlding Project," an open-ended multimedia assignment towards the end of the semester.
I greatly improved upon my writing skills and learned how to concisely and clearly prove a point via literary analysis.
Learned to read a lot of pages really quickly and analyze archival/secondary resources through the Yale Library system.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The greatest strength of this course was Professor Xiang's leadership in class. It seems hard to lead zoom classes, but she did a good job. I also liked many of the readings, especially A Grain of Wheat by Ngugi wa Thiong'o. 

The greatest weakness of this course was probably its early start time. I know this sounds like a ridiculous thing to critique, especially during a time when all courses are online and it seems like it should be easier for students to attend early classes. Still, a lot of students came to class very tired, and because zoom classes are already lower energy than in-person classes, this definitely affected the discussions sometimes.
I loved the readings but there were too many to really fully dig into each one. In the future, I would suggest reading one less text and allocating that time to the rest of the books read in class.

I think one of the key aspects of the course's success was introduced at the very start of class by Prof. Xiang -- she told us that everyone would be given the same participation grade at the end of the semester. This was more of a mental shift than anything, but it immediately made discussion much more welcoming and collaborative during a semester of Zoom where online courses often hurt the interpersonal nature of discussion-based seminars. I think this was something unique to this semester to help create common ground with everyone while we were all scattered throughout the country. With that being said, we were able to really delve into the readings and discuss freely with each other, without some of the pressures of being evaluated at each contribution. The assignments throughout the semester were also well thought out and structured, and the readings were also genuinely interesting. I would just say I wish all my courses had a shared participation grade - I think it does wonders for making the class environment more welcoming, and I think it makes sitting in front of a screen for an hour more enjoyable as well.

Given the nature of the course, it felt like the texts did not build upon one another (was more like a surface level survey of texts from some areas). It honestly felt more like a post-colonial literature course, but regardless, I enjoyed the diversity of the authors whose works we read.

The course follows a natural progression for learning, and Prof. Xiang brought in several authors/speakers, which was interesting. I wish the syllabus didnt focus so heavily on colonialism, but I guess that cant be helped in an anglophone world literature class. A lot of the books on the syllabus were just hard to read/get into in general, except Tiangs State of Emergency, which was amazing. I wish some of the assignments could have been broken up into smaller parts, but thats kind of what I expected from a higher-level English course anyways.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Any moment where a video, an audio segment could be played -- something that allows our brains to rest -- was very helpful and appreciated. I think all professors need to understand, if they don't already, that being in front of a screen is a lot more taxing than sitting in on an in-person lecture or seminar. Implementing some form of break for eye-strain, for mental concentration, in the form of a multimedia clip or any sort of breather, would be immensely appreciated by any student.

I think this course was relatively successful in engaging the students, largely because of the small class size. If this course was to be taught remotely again, I think keeping the class under 10 people is absolutely vital.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would, especially to English majors who are looking to fulfill their requirements.
Yes! Professor Xiang is incredible and this is a great introduction to the major.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially a student who wants to take an accessible English literature course that may not be comfortable yet with academic writing and wants to improve. For an English major, this would also be a great class, as the readings are diverse and interesting, and Prof. Xiang did an excellent job of bringing together a group of students from a variety of classes and majors to think and learn together this past semester.
Personally, I wasn't a hug fan of the course itself, but I do think it tremendously pushed me to grow as a writer. However, if Sunny is teaching this class again, then I highly recommend you take it.
Id recommend this to students who are already used to reading and writing at a high intensity. I would also recommend Xiangs section of 128shes amazing!
